body: @jacktose How have you setup your Bash completion and what is your `bash --version` and `which bash` output?
I'm guessing we need to port https://github.com/Homebrew/brew/commit/a6704b815c28b88e2875725afc486502e1686782 to the bash completions too.

> what is your `bash --version` and `which bash` output?

```shell
$ echo "$SHELL"
/bin/bash

$ which -a bash
/usr/bin/bash
/bin/bash

$ /usr/bin/bash --version
GNU bash, version 5.1.16(1)-release (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu)
Copyright (C) 2020 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later <http://gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html>

This is free software; you are free to change and redistribute it.
There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.

$ /bin/bash --version
GNU bash, version 5.1.16(1)-release (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu)
...
```

> How have you setup your Bash completion?

The short version is
```shell
source /home/linuxbrew/.linuxbrew/etc/bash_completion.d/brew
source /usr/share/bash-completion/bash_completion
```

<details>
<summary>The long version is that my `~/.bashrc` has a bunch of conditional logic for different systems, including these bits, which resolve as above on this system:</summary>

```shell
    if [ ! -r "${HOMEBREW_PREFIX}/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh" ]; then
        # If that exists (from `bash-completion` formula), it will have
        # automatically sourced completions. Otherwise, do it manually:
        for COMPLETION in "${HOMEBREW_PREFIX}/etc/bash_completion.d/"*; do
            [ -r "${COMPLETION}" ] && source "${COMPLETION}"
        done

# activate bash-completion
if [[ $PS1 ]]; then  # interactive shell
    if   [[ -r "/usr/share/bash-completion/bash_completion" ]]; then
        . "/usr/share/bash-completion/bash_completion"
    elif [[ -r "/usr/local/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh" ]]; then
        . "/usr/local/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh"
    elif can_brew && [[ -r "$(brew --prefix)/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh" ]]; then
        . "$(brew --prefix)/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh"
    elif [[ -r "$HOME/.linuxbrew/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh" ]]; then
        . "$HOME/.linuxbrew/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh"
    fi
fi
```
</details>

I have the same experience on another system, with CentOS 7 & Bash 4. It's not what I'm mainly reporting on because it's a non-standard install and all kinds of buggered. But for another example:

```shell
centos $ echo "$SHELL"
/bin/bash

centos $ which -a bash
/bin/bash
/usr/bin/bash

centos $ /bin/bash --version
GNU bash, version 4.2.46(2)-release (x86_64-redhat-linux-gnu)
Copyright (C) 2011 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later <http://gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html>

This is free software; you are free to change and redistribute it.
There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.

centos $ /usr/bin/bash --version
GNU bash, version 4.2.46(2)-release (x86_64-redhat-linux-gnu)
...
```
And the same `.bashrc` which means effectively:
```shell
source /usr/lusers/jacktose/homebrew/etc/bash_completion.d/brew
source /usr/share/bash-completion/bash_completion
```

issue.title: completions: ignore errors on cask list generation.

repository.name: brew
repository.description: üç∫ The missing package manager for macOS (or Linux)

issue.body:
These will always error on Linux.

Fixes #16424

body:
Updated to 4.2.4 and the cask error no longer shows, but completion is still broken for `upgrade` vs `uninstall` (which I assume should pull from the same list):

```shell
$ brew update
Already up-to-date.
$ brew --version
Homebrew 4.2.4
$ brew dr
Your system is ready to brew.

$ brew uninstall libg[Tab]it2  # completes instantly
$ brew upgrade libg[Tab]  # now hangs for ~8s then bells, without completing
```
@jacktose Can you open a new issue?

issue.title: Completion broken for `brew upgrade` on Linux

labels.name: outdated
labels.description: PR was locked due to age

repository.name: brew
repository.description: üç∫ The missing package manager for macOS (or Linux)

issue.body:
### `brew doctor` output ```shell Your system is ready to brew. ``` ### Verification - [X] My "`brew doctor` output" above says `Your system is ready to brew.` and am still able to reproduce my issue. - [X] I ran `brew update` twice and am still able to reproduce my issue. - [X] This issue's title and/or description do not reference a single formula e.g. `brew install wget`. If they do, open an issue at https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/issues/new/choose instead. ### `brew config` output
brew config ```shell HOMEBREW_VERSION: 4.2.4 ORIGIN: https://github.com/Homebrew/brew HEAD: 1c612baa096c69f2fcb221c74e6f5b9979efdcee Last commit: 27 hours ago Core tap JSON: 16 Jan 17:08 UTC HOMEBREW_PREFIX: /home/linuxbrew/.linuxbrew HOMEBREW_CASK_OPTS: [] HOMEBREW_DISPLAY: :0 HOMEBREW_DISPLAY_INSTALL_TIMES: set HOMEBREW_EDITOR: vim HOMEBREW_GITHUB_API_TOKEN: set HOMEBREW_MAKE_JOBS: 20 Homebrew Ruby: 3.1.4 => /home/linuxbrew/.linuxbrew/Homebrew/Library/Homebrew/vendor/portable-ruby/3.1.4/bin/ruby CPU: 20-core 64-bit unknown_0x6_0x9a Clang: N/A Git: 2.34.1 => /bin/git Curl: 7.81.0 => /bin/curl Kernel: Linux 5.15.133.1-microsoft-standard-WSL2 x86_64 GNU/Linux OS: Ubuntu 22.04.3 LTS (jammy) WSL: 2 (Microsoft Store) Host glibc: 2.35 /usr/bin/gcc: 11.4.0 /usr/bin/ruby: N/A glibc: N/A gcc@11: N/A gcc: N/A xorg: N/A ```
### What were you trying to do (and why)? Use tab-completion (in bash) to upgrade a formula without typing its full name (because I'm lazy and/or don't want to misspell it). ### What happened (include all command output)? ```shell $ brew uninstall libg[Tab] # Instantly completes to: $ brew uninstall libgit2 $ brew upgrade libg[Tab] # Hangs ~7s then bells. Never completes. # Apparently still in the middle of typing the command, so: $ brew upgrade libg[Enter] Error: No available formula with the name "libg". Did you mean libgr? ``` ### What did you expect to happen? Formula name should autocomplete without error. Notably, completion works fine for `brew uninstall`, which I assume should pull from the same list of options. ```shell $ brew uninstall libg[Tab] # Instantly completes to: $ brew uninstall libgit2 ``` ### Step-by-step reproduction instructions (by running `brew` commands) ```shell [Run homebrew on linux] brew install [formula] brew upgrade [partial formula name][Tab] ``` ### Bash completion info > what is your `bash --version` and `which bash` output? ```shell $ echo "$SHELL" /bin/bash $ which -a bash /usr/bin/bash /bin/bash $ /usr/bin/bash --version GNU bash, version 5.1.16(1)-release (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu) Copyright (C) 2020 Free Software Foundation, Inc. License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later This is free software; you are free to change and redistribute it. There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law. $ /bin/bash --version GNU bash, version 5.1.16(1)-release (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu) ... ``` > How have you setup your Bash completion? The short version is ```shell source /home/linuxbrew/.linuxbrew/etc/bash_completion.d/brew source /usr/share/bash-completion/bash_completion ```
The long version is that my `~/.bashrc` has a bunch of conditional logic for different systems, including these bits, which resolve as above on this system: ```shell if [ ! -r "${HOMEBREW_PREFIX}/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh" ]; then # If that exists (from `bash-completion` formula), it will have # automatically sourced completions. Otherwise, do it manually: for COMPLETION in "${HOMEBREW_PREFIX}/etc/bash_completion.d/"*; do [ -r "${COMPLETION}" ] && source "${COMPLETION}" done # activate bash-completion if [[ $PS1 ]]; then # interactive shell if [[ -r "/usr/share/bash-completion/bash_completion" ]]; then . "/usr/share/bash-completion/bash_completion" elif [[ -r "/usr/local/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh" ]]; then . "/usr/local/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh" elif can_brew && [[ -r "$(brew --prefix)/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh" ]]; then . "$(brew --prefix)/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh" elif [[ -r "$HOME/.linuxbrew/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh" ]]; then . "$HOME/.linuxbrew/etc/profile.d/bash_completion.sh" fi fi ```
### Another example
I have the same experience on another system, with CentOS 7 & Bash 4. It's not what I'm mainly reporting on because it's a non-standard install and all kinds of buggered. But for another example: ```shell centos $ echo "$SHELL" /bin/bash centos $ which -a bash /bin/bash /usr/bin/bash centos $ /bin/bash --version GNU bash, version 4.2.46(2)-release (x86_64-redhat-linux-gnu) Copyright (C) 2011 Free Software Foundation, Inc. License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later This is free software; you are free to change and redistribute it. There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law. centos $ /usr/bin/bash --version GNU bash, version 4.2.46(2)-release (x86_64-redhat-linux-gnu) ... ``` And the same `.bashrc` which means effectively: ```shell source /usr/lusers/jacktose/homebrew/etc/bash_completion.d/brew source /usr/share/bash-completion/bash_completion ```
### Related issue I reported this in its previous form in #16424. #16452 hid the stderr message, but the failed completion remains an issue.
